content: another design from wandering cat studio seamless kitty cat hat this pattern has been adapted from an out-of-print pattern from the early 80s these hats were a staple of my childhood with my mom knitting them for me and every kid she could find to wear them as the years have gone on and my family and friends have begun having children i ve car- ried on the tradition of knitting kitty balaclavas for all the original pattern was knit flat with several seams and i thought it would be wonderful to be able to knit it seamlessly with only a couple of ends to weave in after casting off it took a few tries but i ve managed it with cleverly placed short row and decreases the result is the same adorable hat with a much more satisfying finish whether you ve knit the origi- nal or are trying this for the first time i hope you enjoy it and continue to spread the joy and warmth that only knitted cat ears can happy knitting valerie materials sizes approximately 200 yards of worsted weight yarn to fit ages 2 4 6 years 4 5 mm circular needle/dpns pattern is written for smallest size additional two stitch markers sizes are provided in parentheses darning needle gauge stitch holder 5 sts and 6 5 row = 1 inch sin stocking stitch copyright statement pattern designed by valerie johnson wandering cat studio 2019 user may not copy and/or distribute pattern for profit or otherwise seamless kitty cat hat page 2 notes hat is started from face opening then knit flat for head increasing and short row with decreasing shape the ears the back is then completed and attached to side with short row and decreasing the neck is picked up and knit in the round for an entirely seamless knit i work the knit stitches of my ribbing through the back of the loop however if you don t like knit- ting through the back of the loop on the ribbing you can always do regular ribbing i do it because my gauge on ribbing isn t great and the twisted stitches make it look neater if you prefer you can use markers in when com- pleting the short row for the back placing them in the gap created by the turn but you will need to move them as you work i prefer not to used mark- ers but do whatever works best for you i made the hat on a circular needle using the magic loop method when necessary but you can used any combination of circular/dpns/straight needles that works for you abbreviations and stitches next row p30 31 31 pm p24 24 26 pm p to end k =knit next row k to 1 stitch before marker kfb sm kfb k to 1 p = purl stitch before marker kfb sm kfb k to end 88 90 92 sl = slip_stitch next
